SQL Blocks

Sometimes it is useful to add SQL statements into a Malloy file. You can do so by using the sql: keyword in combination with SQL literals, which are enclosed between an opening || and a closing ;;.

sql: my_sql_query is ||
  SELECT
    first_name,
    last_name,
    gender
  FROM malloy-data.ecomm.users
  LIMIT 10
;;
QUERY RESULTS
first_​namelast_​namegender
ROBERTHELTONMale
MICHAELBULLOCKMale
JOHNWHITMIREMale
MICHAELHUBBARDMale
JEREMYVALVOMale
[
  {
    "first_name": "ROBERT",
    "last_name": "HELTON",
    "gender": "Male"
  },
  {
    "first_name": "MICHAEL",
    "last_name": "BULLOCK",
    "gender": "Male"
  },
  {
    "first_name": "JOHN",
    "last_name": "WHITMIRE",
    "gender": "Male"
  },
  {
    "first_name": "MICHAEL",
    "last_name": "HUBBARD",
    "gender": "Male"
  },
  {
    "first_name": "JEREMY",
    "last_name": "VALVO",
    "gender": "Male"
  }
]

  SELECT
    first_name,
    last_name,
    gender
  FROM malloy-data.ecomm.users
  LIMIT 10

Sources from SQL Blocks

Sources can be created from a SQL block, e.g.

sql: my_sql_query is ||
  SELECT
    first_name,
    last_name,
    gender
  FROM malloy-data.ecomm.users
  LIMIT 10
;;

source: limited_users is from_sql(my_sql_query) {
  measure: user_count is count()
}

query: limited_users -> {
  aggregate: user_count
}
QUERY RESULTS
user_​count
10
[
  {
    "user_count": 10
  }
]
SELECT 
   COUNT( 1) as user_count
FROM (
  SELECT
    first_name,
    last_name,
    gender
  FROM malloy-data.ecomm.users
  LIMIT 10
) as limited_users
ORDER BY 1 desc
